title: Redesigned belt tensioner for Vertex Velleman K8400

description.text: Original belt tensioners are not really ideal. This mod kit replaces them allowing a proper way of tensioning and adjusting the belt.

Print in the same orientation as in the picture. If you just want to replace the original, you can print only the locking piece.stl for both shaft ends. You will not get full adjustability, but tensioning the belt is significantly easier than originally. If you want the full kit, use locking piece.stl at the other end of the shaft and adjusting piece.stl + belt tensioner.stl on the other end.
Mount the locking piece first and then adjust shaft aligment using these http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:606083 and secure the adjusting piece.

description.text:
***Added 'better bell crank' and 'links only' stl's. Based on Persona's really cool instructable:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Mechanical-Claw-Ring/ Something about this design really mesmerized me (watch the GIF on the instructable). So I imported it to Skecthup and used it as a template, tweaking in ways I thought the 3-d print would need it.

Update:  I added 2 stl's--a stronger bell crank, and one for the links only because they are delicate.  My printer likes the new crank better, and the links file is in case one breaks.  
All the pins for the links are made from 3mm filament with the ends melted a bit and then squished flat against a glass.  
The round piece is to hold the bell crank in place, just glue it on (but check for fit first).  
The pieces that print up between the jaws are printed upside down, they are meant to be flipped over and glued in place to hold the fulcrum of the claw pieces (see picture where the claw pieces attach to the main body).  
Mine printed okay at .35 layers (.5 nozzle), with 20% fill, except that a couple pieces needed some light sanding to fit well with the other pieces.  
With a 1mm brim, the link pieces print out stronger I think, I strongly recommend this.  
Oh, one last thing.  At first the mechanism was sticky and felt like it was hanging up.  I doused the whole thing in cooking oil, and worked it through the joints, then washed all the oil off with dish soap and water, and it's great--works smoothly, and it's not oily.

The fan points at the back of the nozzle by default/design.  You can remove a screw and rotate it so it points better at the nozzle but I made this instead.  Seems to work just fine.  
Printed Solid at 0.25mm layer height on my D5S.  
I had an issue with the corners lifting so stuck some mouse ears on them.  There's a version with and a version without them.  
Might work on other printers, I just don't know.  
If anyone has any suggestions to improve this let me know...  
Update:  Seemed like it was pushing air slightly the wrong place and maybe cooling the nozzle too much.  I have uploaded a 'v2' which shrinks the aperture a bit.  I also added a little deflector to it which may or may not help.   Seems to look like it points in a better place now anyway will try some longer prints tomorrow and see what the temperatures are reading.

I wanted to try and just reuse the screw that come with the original mount.  They aren't going to be that strong but there's no load on them really so it should be fine.  They seem to grip and tap themselves and all is holding firm.  
Just remove the old one and insert the new one.  Simples!  
The original version seems like it might be cooling the hot end too much.  I've tried to adjust it in v2 by closing the aperture and adding some slight deflection.  I've not had the chance to test it much tonight.

description.text:
Traubenzucker Box - Glucose Box  
Traubenzucker für Diabetiker. Um Unterzuckerungen zu Hause oder Unterwegs gegenzusteuern, ist es sehr ratsam schnellwirkenden Zucker (Traubenzucker) schnell zur Hand zu haben. Der im Handel angebotene Traubenzucker ist sehr empfindlich und sollte in einer Box transportiert werden. Dieses habe ich mir mit einer kleine Schiebebox verwirklicht. Rot ist auch gut, denn dann wissen Fremde, wonach sie suchen müssen. Um Änderungen anzubringen, z.B. einen Schriftzug eigener Wahl, gebe ich den Originalfile für FREECAD mit bei.  
Glucose for diabetics. To counteract hypoglycemia at home or on the road, it is highly advisable fast-acting sugar (glucose) to have at hand. The glucose sold in shops is very sensitive and should be transported in a box. This I have realized with a small sliding box. Red is also good because I know strangers, what to look for. In order to make changes, such as a logo of your choice, I give the original file for FREECAD in with. (translated by Google)

title: Up! Plus+ Build Platform Sliding Track

description.text:
Slide your build platform into place and not have to worry about screws or binder clips getting in the way of the extruder. (using maint. tool, the extruder will never hit the platform track) *Eliminates Gekko Board warping. *I have found that once my Gekko board has flattened out better from using this, it now is able to slide around once fully heated. If you are getting prints with offset layers, use a binder clip instead of the printed plastic clip in the front. You will need (7) M3x6 Button Head screws.
http://www.mcmaster.com/#92855A307

Print at an angle to get it to fit on your build platform, with the largest surface flat on the build platform and the short piece verticle. TEST FIT IT BEFORE PRINTING!!!
Before powering up your printer, install the tracks, and lift (by hand) the platform all the way up to the top. Hold it there and slide the platform back and forth. make sure the tracks don't add any friction to the movement of the platform. If they do, you will need to sand down the sides of the tracks until they clear the sides of the printer. My first ones fit after sanding, second ones fit without modification, so check it! I recommend giving it an acetone wipe to strengthen it, but you must let it dry for 48hrs before installing it if you do. Updated files 4/7/13: New (Alternate) Front clips stay attached stronger, but are a little trickier to get on. (bending tab removed, snap on now) Side clips are .5mm thinner and no longer tapered for better printing, and more clearance between bed and posts.

comments.text:
Wow these clamps saved my part! I set the machine to print ran out the door to work i made them out of PLA and print with abs when the hot abs nozzle hit the clamp it melted it out of the way instantly instead of launching a clip inside my machine Again, and it didnt jam my table up causing me to have to take it apart and move the belt tensioner back to where it should be. I love these clamps cant thank you enough you just saved me 68g abs and hours of repair work on my machine. I now print and dont worry i have flawless prints now and my machine does not screw up thanks again.
And the garolite plate i got from octave is warped like hell i wouldnt try it with these clamps.

remixed_from.author: Arakon
remixed_from.title: Simple Mobius gimbal for X520 frame

description.text:
Update 22.02.2015:
Test flight video added.
http://youtu.be/4lyIlt7PwZo
Some shakiness, but I think this comes from a badly adjusted gimbal rather than actual vibrations, due to the nature of the vibrations.

The original design with the forward facing anti-vibration balls tended to bounce in strong winds.. this is an attempt to increase stability by using the balls in the way they are intended, under pressure from above.
Note that I was not able to actually test it in flight yet.
Photos show the first prototype, I made some small changes to slim down the motor mount plate and rotate the motor by 90° since, but didn't bother to print it again yet.
All except for the plate and mount are identical to my previous design and can simply be used again. The Gimbal Mount file has the rubber ball holes closed on purpose to allow printing a smaller hole on top of a bigger one. The closed area will only be a single layer thick, cut/drill open and file or sand the edges a litte bit. Loosely based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:688504, although by far not as pretty.

Printed in ABS, 40% infill, sliced with Slic3r 1.2.5. Print without supports.  
Only requires 2 M3x10 screws with a washer each to mount.  
The Gimbal Mount file has the rubber ball holes closed on purpose to allow printing a smaller hole on top of a bigger one. The closed area will only be a single layer thick, cut/drill open and file or sand the edges a litte bit.

title: Raspberry Pi B+ Case for Printrbot Simple Metal, Right-Side Version

description.text: This is is a modified version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:673133/, an awesome Raspberry Pi B+ case and mount for the Printrbot Simple Metal made by nmakes ( http://www.thingiverse.com/nmackes). I wanted to mount mine to the right side of my printer instead of the left, so I swapped the mounting bracket to the other side in TinkerCAD. Be sure to check out the Raspberry Pi Camera mount that goes along with this case at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:442063 by Jerware (http://www.thingiverse.com/Jerware/about). Since you'll need the mounting hole and you're going to attach this to the right-hand side of the printer, you'll want to use the normal "arm.stl" file instead of the flipped or reinforced versons.
See the instructions from the original case: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:673133/#instructions

description.text: As with the other famous Philly structures I've found to date on Thingiverse, this began life as a Sketchup Warehouse file. I live by the Art Museum and wanted a model of it I could print, so inspired by the work others had done on the Comcast Tower, Liberty Place and City Hall, I grabbed the Sketchup file. I then simplified that model, converted it to an STL and cleaned it up for printing. Enjoy!

1) Print with support, flatten the base yourself or wait for me to do so. The model itself doesn't require support, just the underside of the hill it sits on.
2) Hum the Rocky theme while it's printing and imagine a tiny Rocky running the steps triumphantly.

title: Kossel idler flanges for standard Ball Bearing (parameterized)

description.text: This is an adapter for an standard ball bearing (608ZZ in my case) for a Kossel Idler when you don't have flanged ones available. It is parammeterized in OpenScad, so just modify with your specification. It does not rotate with bearing as it adapts only to its inner ring, leaving the outer ring free to move with timing belt (GT2). I do prefer this to those caps adapters that force the belt to have friction with plastic as that would reduce timing belt life.

title: Wireless QI charger base for Nexus 7

description.text:
I kept having some trouble with the wireless QI charger for my Nexus 7, so I decided to build a base that would house both in the perfect spot for the best wireless connection. I've uploaded the sketchup file so anyone can modify the original design to fit their own wireless charger and Nexus 7 2013 case. I printed this in red abs with 20% infill. I had to use rectilinear infill and finish modes, as the typical archimedean chords I typically use kept crashing Slic3r on this specific design. I would recommend cutting out some of the base to save some ABS, and also widening the walls around the Nexus 7. The 4mm walls really didn't do so well and split when I printed them. I'd recommend widening them more to 7mm or 10mm if you can spare the plastic. The overhang of the tablet at the top of the base was by design. My Printing area can only handle 200mm on the X and y axis. I am using the Poetic Revolution case for Nexus 7 FHD 2013 model.
http://www.amazon.com/Poetic-REVOLUTION-Android-Manufacturer-Warranty/dp/B00E7FY8P2 The wireless QI charger I have is this one:
http://www.amazon.com/Wireless-Charging-Plate-Smart-phones/dp/B00HJ2KEMQ/ref=sr_1_14?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1424476030&sr=1-14&keywords=wireless+qi+charger

This is exactly what the title implies - a hinge for the top of a standard 1 gallon paint can. I got the idea directly from this part (http://www.youtube.com/v/DjCPS6FD7RM?version=3&start=57&end=83&autoplay=0&hl=en_US&rel=0) of a tips and tricks video by Jimmy DiResta. He uses it for a can of Bondo body filler, but I thought that I might be able to make a printable version for a standard paint can. It is used to easily open and close the paint can without touching the lid (to avoid messy hands) The largest part is just under 9 x 4 x 1 centimeters, so it should be able to print easily on most printers. The hole in the hinge is sized to fit a 1/4 inch bolt. All credit goes to the ingenious Jimmy DiResta for the design idea.

I have not yet printed this design, but it is very simple so I don't foresee any issues. Just print one of the file named "paintcanhinge_arm" and two of "paintcanhinge_support". Then slide and fasten a 1/4inch bolt into the hole. Hot glue (or use the adhesion method of your choice) the apparatus on the paint can and paint away with clean hand (from opening the lid at least).

description.text:
I've been trying out a pair of snowshoes on extended loan from a friend. They work well, except the bindings rely entirely on tension to keep the straps secure. Unless the straps were pulled super tight and kept taut by the presence of your foot, they could flop around and disengage from the pin that keeps them connected.  
I could see that all it would take to keep the straps engaged on the pin was something to hold them together when folded back. So, I designed this clip to do the job. (I've since looked at similar snowshoes in the store, and was pleased to see their bindings include very similar clips. I suspect these originally did as well.)  
Of course this clip isn't snowshoe-specific. I suppose you could use it anywhere you need to hold two straps or thin objects together.

I printed six at 0.3 mm layer height with 3 perimeters and no infill or top/bottom layers. The perimeters take up most of the space with the default clip wall thickness, and leaving the interior unfilled helps with springiness of objects like this anyway.
This is a bracket to hold the bottom of window blinds. The screw holes are spaced about 20mm apart. It works great to keep the blinds from swinging around when the door is opened/closed.

remixed_from.title: Laser-cut Laptop Stand for Macbook Air

title: laser cut portable laptop stand 1/8th inch acrylic

description.text:
This laptop stand was inspired by the Laser-cut Laptop Stand for Macbook Air by AndrewSleigh. Here's what's new: 1) asymmetrical joints that click together. The male joint on the crossbar squeezes the sides of the laptop stand and snaps into place in a hole above the main cut on the female joint. The crossbar is also shorter on the edges to prevent snapping if a person dissembles the sides one at a time.
2) ridges to keep the laptop from skiing off the front of the stand
3) round corners to protect hands during assembly

This stand is laser cut out of acrylic advertised as 1/8th inch. To test that the joints are tight, try cutting the "joint_test" file and seeing if those pieces make a small "clicking sound when you put them together. If they are too loose or too tight, adjust the tolerances at the joints.

title: Filament Guide Pulley for Maketbot or Thing-O-Matic

description.text: This filament guide pulley allows me to put a CAT-6 box loaded with ABS filament on the floor, run the filament up and over the pulley, and down into the extruder. It is low friction, large diameter and has a deep slot to help guide the filament.

!! YOU WILL NEED THE FULL 100mm x 100mm BUILD SURFACE !! If you have not replaced your build platform screws with flush head screws, this build is not for you. It will drive your extruder into the raised screw heads. Fair warning. See the attached image for an example full build platform. The thing is designed in OpenSCAD, and it is my first OpenSCAD design, so my apologies in advance for the code. The Filament_Pulley_SCAD_STL_0v0.zip includes: //The OpenSCAD design file
Filament_Pulley_0v0.scad //High resolution STL of both parts of the holder, ready to Skeinforge Holder_Two_Halves_0v0.stl (print 1 copy) //High resolution STL of half the pulley, ready to Skeinforge

author: MiseryBot

description.text:
Working on a power system for my SLR rig using RC batteries from hobbyking and the like. The goal here is to be able to accommodate multiple sizes of battery without swapping things on and off the rails or dealing with a complex lock system. The hex holes are for running bungee cords through, the cutout slots on the back and bottom of the tray for running wires. You could also feasibly use a strap system. Requires two M4 nuts, and two 24mm M4 bolts. Hole dimensions calculated with:
y = 1.0155x + 0.2795 vertical
y = 0.9927x + 0.3602 horizontal
(source: https://innovationstation.utexas.edu/tip-design)

and ugly lamp shade, to cover more ugly bare light bulbs
First Go to learn: Lessons learned:
  • ABS has the habit to deform on thin long walls
  • for light, it's important to have same thickness for all walls & curves
  • printing area can be bigger than heating bed!
    (redesign of my hydron is in progress)

Printed in ABS, due to temperature concerns with PLA. The walls are 1 mm; so are the curves all round
Bottom is 0.95 mm (adjusted to fit layer/first heights
printed with 0.4 nozzle & 0.5 extrusion width.
Layer height 0.2, first layer 0.35 Extrusions multiplier slightly elevated (3-5%) produced a better closing wall, still warped, but less gaps.

So we're going to post a game aid soon that'll give the rules, but its actually pretty simple, so here's the breakdown: Basically, everyone playing puts their tiles in one bag (10 tiles from each player). Place one tile in the center of the play space (and maybe mark it with a die or something) and then take turns filling the board in outward from the center. Once its all placed, the first player will place their base tile at the furthest point from the center and each other player will place furthest from the center and each others base tiles. description.text:
Hanging a plane on the wall with a finishing nail isn't going to cut it in my house, especially since the Bix2 is fitted with a lot of expensive FPV gear.  This is a man's house, and a man knows that nails and gypsum board don't mix.  
In this remix, I added 2mm girth and a larger hole for a suitable fastener.

Don't mess around. Print this studly little hanger with the text facing up on 0.3/fast at 100%. Anchor with a 1-1/2" #8 screw to the wall, using a matching plug - or stud. In case your daddy never showed you how, here's a video. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kFLxQ9aNlrY Tip: hang the plane high so that the tail is up out of harm's way. title: "Nukulele" Playable soprano Ukulele, sounds great printable without supports.

description.text:
I designed this Ukulele after printing a few of the other Ukes on Thingiverse that were good but still had room for improvement.
Improvements include:
No buzzing
No sharp corners
Doesn't get out of tune on the higher frets.
2 halves fit together properly
machines fit great. The 2 parts fit together snugly for me there was no need for glue but depending on your printer/slicer you may need to.
You will need 4 Uke machine heads just google B00EQ29KNG and you'll find the ones I used. I bought some machine heads that were too long so I made a spacer block you can add to the back so everything will still work properly.
also you will need 4 Ukelele strings.
You will need a print area at least 10.5" tall.
If you want to print this on a smaller printer let me know what size you have and I can try to split it up for you so you can glue the parts together.
I've improved everything I could think of but if you feel like there is something that could be better please let me know!
All feedback is welcome. 02/21/2015 - Added new files with neck and body cut in half for a smaller height requirement (now 5.35" or 136 mm tall) I haven't tried gluing these halves together so let me know how that works for you. 02/28/2015 - Added a spacer that you can add to the back of the head if your tuners are too long.

Designed in SolidWorks
Sliced with KISSlicer
Printed in PLA 2mm skin thickness 20% infill 220°

I have cut the neck and body in half to accommodate printers that are vertically challenged. They should still print fine as long as you have good adhesion, adding a brim wouldn't hurt either. author: Rips

description.text:
This is a parametric openscad script that will generate a tile. The tile has notches in it that will mesh with other copies of the tile. This will allow you to print out and assemble a rectilinear box of any size/shape. (with the adhesive of your choice)
Particularly useful if you want to make a box that's too big to fit inside the build volume of your printer.
while you can just print out the components of a box, you can also use some of the optional sections of the code to add functional features to the tiles.
1) A button. Basically, this feature allows you to weaken a particular area so that when you press on it the plastic deforms and presses a button inside.
2) Cips. You can add little clips to the tips of some of the notches so that instead of being a solid box it can have a lid that easily attaches and detaches.
3) A platform. The clips need a bit of clearance to work properly, so the bottom of the box (that's mounted to something) should be raised up off of the mounting surface.
4) Fan mount. If the tile is big enough, you can add a hole (plus four screw holes) and mount a 40mm fan.

Download the openscad script. It has comments that show you which variables to edit to get the tile you want. (openscad works in millimeters)
You will have to measure the volume you want to enclose and work out the appropriate tile dimensions.
The number of notches in each edge of the tile doesn't really matter.
The geometry of the notches changes as the thickness of the tile changes, so that the notches will fit flush with each other no matter if the tiles form a flat surface or a corner.
You can adjust the x and y dimensions independently. This means you can create any rectangle that will fit on your build platform, with any combination of notches (as long as they're all the same for the same box). If you start using rectangles you'll probably need to print out more than one shape of tile. Keep in mind that the notches will extend the dimensions you specify by half of the thickness of the tile.
Keep in mind that sometimes the tiles can be mirrored no problem, but if you start adding features the mirrored tile will put them in the wrong place.

title: GoPro Gimbal (For GoPro + its waterproof case)

description.text: This is a GoPro gimbal that allows you to mount the GoPro in its waterproof case. I didn't see one available so I designed one myself, and had some fun using it snowboarding. Here's a video of the results: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tE9L6f0Ab7g I have included the original sketchup file too. You might need the latest version, but I have included sketchup 2013 and 2014 files just in case. It really could use some stabilisation on the third axis, with a smooth follow-me setting. I leave that as an exercise for the viewer. You need to buy your own hollow shaft motors and a gimbal controller. Parts list is in the instructions. Have fun!

Here's what you'll need

  • DYS hollow shaft gimbal x2: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__67557__DYS_Hollow_Shaft_2606_Brushless_Gimbal_Motor_BGM2606_90_.html

  • Micro alexmos 2-axis brushless gimbal controller x1: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__53726__Quanum_Micro_AlexMos_Brushless_Gimbal_Controller_2_Axis_Kit_Basecam_SimpleBGC_.html

  • Velcro strap x2: get it from your local hardware place.

  • Soldering iron + thin heatshrink.

  • Soft, thin silicone wires. Anything above 24awg will work, but space is extremely tight so I recommend getting the thinnest you can fit. 28awg is great too.

  • Some tweezers or something to help you route the wires.

  • Conformal coating spray.
    • Basic tips Assembly is straight forward but here are some tips.

  • When purchasing from hobbyking for the first time, you will not have access to the small discount that regular buyers do. A trick is to stay on the product page for a few minutes, and you may get a pop up telling you of a "one time only offer" which will give you a small discount on the parts you want to buy. It may not happen on all components and the price is just the regular buying registered user price, but it's something.

  • During assembly, the most important thing is that both your IMU wires and your pitch-axis motor wires are routed carefully through the hole and slot that is available on the two motors and the "L" shaped bracket.

  • It will be extremely tricky to route the wires through the slot on the back of the wrist mount. If you can't, just tape it down.

  • The lid for the controller is held down by tape too.

  • You will have to cut your wires to get them to fit, then extend them. Extend the wires by soldering them together as you go. Be very careful not to melt your plastic!

  • You will have to cut a hole in the lid to get the main power leads out. You can change it in the file itself if you want.

  • There are more tips and descriptions in the skp file.

  • Can't help you with the tuning of the gimbal, I'm afraid. Just grab the correct version of the SimpleBGC configuration tool, and remember to do your 6-axis calibration.
    • My Settings WARNING: THESE ARE FOR REFERENCE ONLY! SETTINGS WILL DIFFER BASED ON ALL SORTS OF THINGS! IMPROPER SETTINGS CAN MELT YOUR MOTORS AND DO OTHER KINDS OF DAMAGE! Use at your own risk! In SimpleBGC Gui v 2.40 b7, these are just the settings I changed. Basic tab PID Controller
    Roll P / I / D: 10, 0.04, 6
    Pitch P/ I / D: 11, 0.06, 6
    Limit accelerations checked at 500d/sec Motor Configuration
    Roll power 120, num.poles 13
    Pitch power 120, num.poles 13 Sensor
    Get your axes looking right in the preview, and you should be OK. This tells the software, based on the IMU position, which way is up and right. Advanced tab Timings
    PWM frequency: HIGH (silent). Setting this to low makes it whine, and you will also have to adjust your PIDs afterwards.

author: scottan

title: RX-LCD5802 Adjustable FPV Mount for Phantom 2 Controller

description.text:
Mount your RX-LCD5802 monitor to your Phantom 2 controller! How to use:
  • Print pieces 'fpvmount' and 'Controller_Mount' (and remove the base plate, e.g. the thin flat bit, from 'Controller_Mount').
  • Attach 'Controller Mount' to your Phantom 2 controller.
  • Align the bolt holes of both pieces.
  • Thread a GoPro bolt through the holes.
  • Place RX-LCD5802 on 'fpvmount' and secure with a short 5.4mm bolt (or similar e.g. 3/16" or 1/4" maybe? Sorry, not sure on sizing American friends!). The length of the bolt I'm using is 13.3mm. Bolt sizes are included in pictures.
    • OPTIONAL: There is provision for a 6-sided 8mm nut on the Controller Mount part (see pictures). You can secure this in place with some long-nosed pliers. NOTE The part which latches onto the controller was taken from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:247161 All credit for this component goes to user 'markloane' (www.thingiverse.com/markloane). Without his work, this would not be possible. The reason that I am re-uploading the component here is because it needed to be re-oriented and have supports added in order to be easily printable. I designed the fpvmount and my father coded it using OpenSCAD. The OpenSCAD file is available for download and modification.

description.text:
A box for the RAMBO controller board. http://www.reprap.org/wiki/rambo My power supply came with a XLR neutrik plug, hence the socket on the front. Stand offs are for M3 screws. They will probably fit without tapping. Box is designed in Autodesk 123D design.
Final design has square holes at the front instead of round ones. PLEASE READ THE INSTRUCTIONS BEFORE PRINTING.

This box has base dimensions of 145mm x 155mm. So you have to pay attention to warping. I printed this in PLA using the following settings, and still it failed. (I did some not so bright things during the print.) And since this is a very time consuming print, I set the print speeds as show below. During my first attempts I experienced a thermal stall in the nozzle, because the filament traversed the melt zone to quickly; so it didn't melt fast enough. The temperatures below works on my ReprapPro Mendel. AND MOST IMPORTANT: I suspect that some of my PLA is contaminated with residue chemicals. If I don't degrease the capton surface the object will surely detach during printing. So give the build platform a solid rub of acetone. First layer settings for a very slow feedrate of 10 mm/s:
Bed temp 45 C
Hotend 190 C
First layer speed 10 mm/s
Advanced extrusion width modifier for First layer: 98% (in Slic3r)
Advanced extrusion width modifier for Infill: 102% (in Slic3r) Subsequent layers feedrate 40-60 mm/s:
Bed temp 45 C
Hotend 210 C
Infill 50% (only the bottom of the box.)
Perimeters 10 (because you don't want to infill the walls. it will shake your printer to pieces).
External Perimeter Speed 40 mm/s
Perimeters Speed 50 mm/s
Infill Speed 50 mm/s
Bridges 60 mm/s
Horizontal Shells: 3 top layers. 1 bottom layer (in Slic3r)
(I forgot rest of the settings, sorry) STL file was reduced slightly in Meshlab.

author: nrb46

description.text:
THE PHOTOS: Are mostly of the OLD design these STLs are meant to pretty-up, but illustrate how to make one without a 3D printer. WHAT IS IT?
A Chording Keyboard is a one-handed (usually) input device, where you type keystrokes by pressing combinations of buttons. Kind of like playing Guitar Hero. It's also called a Keyer. All the commercially available designs are bulky, old, and stupid, but the basic idea of a chording keyboard is a great one for wearable computing. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chording_keyboard
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keyer I've always wanted to produce this design -- poor guy gave up before everyone on the planet had a 3D printer: http://www.xaphoon.com/dataegg/ MY DESIGN:
But my design is nothing of the sort. I put this together a while back, before I had a 3D printer, myself. If you want to go that route, you can... there's no reason to use my STLs, and they're not even complete. So this is basically a very old project I am resurrecting now that I have more resources; but this version is basically the old resource-starved version. It's based around a Nintendo Wii remote. These things are amazing devices for hardware hacking; the wiimote unit itself contains:
  • Several accessable button/switches
  • A speaker
  • 3-Axis Accelerometer
  • BLUETOOTH
  • A point-tracking infrared CAMERA. Seriously!
  • Vibration buzzer
  • Expansion port... with Arduino/ATmega library!!
    • You can find Wiimotes on sale as low as $15; normally about $30. There is no other way to get this kind of functionality attached to an ATMega/Arduino for twice the price. Probably significantly more. WHAT YOU NEED:
    This little project doesn't even use an ATMega or Arduino (yet) - all you need is a wiimote, some appropriate buttons, and a way to put/hold it all together. WHAT YOU GET:
    The only software I am providing assumes you are running Linux, and will only work there. But it would be trivial for anyone with knowledge of their operating system to modify for their purposes; the libraries it relies on are available on all platforms. All you need to do is know how to hook into your OS's input queue so you can imitate a keyboard/mouse. WHAT IT CAN DO:
  • Use the buttons to emulate a keyboard, obviously.
  • Use the accelerometer to emulate a mouse.
  • All this over BLUETOOTH!
    • WIP WHY:
  • Just until I get some STLs that work for this design. I have future designs already under way but they will be separate Thingiverse projects.
  • I'm not uploading the .scad files until I'm done, since Thingiverse refuses to render STLs anymore in a Thing once I've uploaded something it can't render.
    • ABOUT THE STL:
    The STL published is a slightly fixed version of the one in the photos, which has too-thin walls and too little space between index finger and thumb buttons. WHERE THE SOFTWARE LIVES:
    https://github.com/ScribbleJ/WiimoteKeyer

1) Get the source code from my github account: github.com/ScribbleJ 2) Compile it on your machine. On Ubuntu, the steps are: $ sudo aptitude install libcwiid-dev
$ git clone http://github.com/ScribbleJ/WiimoteKeyer.git
$ cd WiimoteKeyer
$ ./make.sh Now you can test it with a Wiimote before you go on. 3) Disassemble a Wiimote. Wire your switches to it. Which button goes to which switch is not important; you can easily change it in the source code and recompile. Don't use the three buttons along the middle on top; those are used here to change to mouse mode and back. (See photos) 4) Mount it all up in some suitable fashion. You will see (OLD!) photos attached of how I originally did this; a rollerblade glove, some carving foam, and lots of electrical tape and hot glue was the first version. The second iteration replaced some of the electrical tape with PCL plastic, which you can form by hand at reasonable temperatures. I guess it's the thing to do before you have a 3D printer. 5) Install something like tuxtype and learn to type all over again!
  • A key is typed when you release the first button of the chord. So you can take your time pressing the buttons down, and if you want to type a letter repeatedly, you only have to let one finger up and down again and up again. Make sense?
  • Modifier keys like SHIFT and ALT apply to the next keystroke. So if you type SHIFT then type E you'll get the E shifted. Simple!
    • EXAMPLE:
    Type an upper-case 'R'.
    a) Look at cheatsheet.txt. This is arranged so one side has the fingers going one way and the other the opposite.
    b) First type SHIFT by clicking the 4th thumb button and releasing it.
    c) R is all the finger buttons together; a full chord. Type an R by pressing in all four finger buttons and then releasing them. I only used it seriously for a couple hours overall and probably got up to about 30WPM. There's no reason you can't go much faster, but it will never be as fast as a keyboard with a separate button for each letter, obviously. :)

THEORY AND DESIGN NOTES:
  • I decided to go with my left hand, so I'd have my right hand free. A better design would allow you to easily clear your hand for other uses.
  • I wrote a perl script (in the source repo) that counts the frequency of characters in text you feed it, and gave it a bunch of things I'd typed lately.
  • I used those along with some intuition about which chord combinations were easiest to reach to decide which characters went with which chords.

comments.text: Might I suggest tactile switches, very small, only require a slight movement, some make an audible click, and inexpensive.  One can scrap lots of them out of the control panel of an old VHS player, stereo or other device that has lots of buttons.
comments.author: terrym

comments.text: Once you program the 328 chip on the ardunino you can pop it out, replace it with another chip that has the boot loader on it.  You can get these chips for just a few dollars and put the bootloader on them yourself. The 328 chip is tiny by itself even with a 16MHz resonator soldered to one side.  Then you can dead bug the arduino to the switches in the handle and  to a cheap wireless sender that only costs a couple of bucks. It should all fit into the grip device in your hand.  Then the only wires in will be for power.  If you do the power management right you might be able to get away with using a coin cell or small rechargeable lithium battery and get a few days of keying out of them before you need to recharge them.
comments.author: BuckRogers1965

comments.author: ScribbleJ

comments.text: I like being able to make one of these simply and cheaply, but I'd like it to be something I really use every day, and for that it would be nice to make something more elegant... even if it costs a bit more.  The Wiimote is an awesome tool but it's a little bulky.
comments.author: Linkreincarnate

comments.text: Have you thought about using a cheap Bluetooth mouse, it's got all the components, low power, wireless, usually more than 5 buttons (if you get one with a scroll wheel) and sometimes a rechargeable a battery.  It'll give you a chance to concentrate on the ergonomics and software without the cost of supporting all of those facilities immediately, and your PC will recognise it.
comments.author: ScribbleJ

title: Removable PVC coupling fastener for Granddad constructions

description.text:
Being a granddad, it is unavoidable to use your tools and garage for building stuf to please your grandchildren. This will start at the age of months, rather than years :-) So, I built a BabyGym for my grandson.
It has been built from PVC tubing, so why post it here? Well, I needed to have the object stowed away when not in use, so some of the couplings are not glued but fastened with a hole and pin construction. This is the pin! Please LIKE before collecting Thomas
www.3Daybreaker.blogspot.com

Please LIKE before collecting Print with 40% infill
File PinPVC_V2 is a reinforced version for the 32mm tube
The original sometimes broke while applying! The design, when succesfull, will be parametric,
beware currently, the code is ok for a 33mm tube with a 5mm hole. The parametric does not work yet. Please wait and watch for other dimensions. Change the code to reflect the measure of the tube you build with and the measure of the hole you drill. Slide the tube in the coupling and drill the hole through both of them in the proper position, Than stick the pin through the hole and all should be fixed :-) BEWARE
this is nor a watertight nor a strong construction,
Don't put force on the coupling and no fluids through the pipes. Thomas
www.3Daybreaker.blogspot.com

title: D5S Fan Housing with air deflector

description.text: See my MK2 version. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:693572 MK1 info: I had made a simple air deflector (blue bit in pics) that fitted to the original fan housing of my D5S and it worked very well at stopping the temps dropping when the fan was on eliminating the need to insulate the hot end. I saw a new fan housing from ElBertie and printed it out as it centralized the fan to the nozzle. I immediately had temp drop problems so I fired up SolidWorks to create my own fan housing with deflector plate built in. So here it is it works very well and it stops the temps dropping and centralizes the nozzle.

I printed this on my Wanhao D5S Mini with the following settings 50% infill
2 outer shells of 0.4mm
No supports Custom marlin firmware.
Simplify3d custom settings 0.2mm Layer height fast settings Time to print 104 mins

description.text: This is a housing/keys for a NRF24L01 based, battery powered Wall mountable Remote Control. The Keys are engineered to be printed in one part (frame and six keys). After printing you can break free the keys and they can be moved then. This Thing is meant to work with the MySensors Porject and your favorite controller e.g. FHEM. The PCB and detailed instructions howto build this thing can be found there: http://forum.mysensors.org/topic/1018/contest-3d-printed-battery-powered-wall-remote-control I did not test the battery run time yet but standby current is r.a. 2.5uA which is much below self discharging, so I expect the remote to work quiet some time on one set of batteries.

Print the parts, get the PCB, solder it, program it.
Much work to do but it gives you a nice Remote Control for your Home Automation Project. Have a look at the MySensors Forum for detailed instructions how to build this thing: http://forum.mysensors.org/topic/1018/contest-3d-printed-battery-powered-wall-remote-control

comments.author: cyberkeiler

description.text: Headphone holder design to be screwed right into a hole in a vertical surface. Includes a hole for a headphone jack

A hard case for a CC3D board (OpenPilot).   
This one has survived several crashes as can see a heavy one in photo, case came unstuck from 3M pad in crash, bounced around a bit but fine, and most importantly CC3D is OK!I   
Designed case as I was finding my Rapman 3.1 was not printing the other designs around that well, this one is fast to print and solid, it's designed for FDM printers.  
Has LED hole for status LEDs. Use M3x15mm anything.

3D Print it!  
Use your favourite plastic to build, case in photo is built with layer thickness 0.5, use your favourite settings though I prefer thicker layers and lots of flow/heat for objects that need some solidity.

I designed this mount for the round heatbed of my delta printer (picture attached). It can be easily adjusted in height. Also it is able to avoid nozzle crashes using a spring as bumper.  
I am using so called "drive-in nuts" (see picture) on the backside of my bottom board to fix the heatbed-mount. But of coursse there are lots of alternatives to do this... its up to you. hope it helps
